title: Vegetarians and the Common Cold: Flaws in the Study
question_text:
Can following a vegetarian diet reduce the occurrence of the common cold? An observational study is being planned to compare the average number of colds self-proclaimed vegetarians suffer from each year with the average number of colds non-vegetarians suffer from each year.
Which of the following represents the biggest problem with this type of study?

choices.text: Blinding is not possible since the individuals in the study will know whether or not they are vegetarian.
It will be impossible to see if there is a relationship between following a vegetarian diet and the occurrence of the common cold.
Confounding could occur. Perhaps vegetarians get fewer colds because they try to follow a healthier overall lifestyle than non-vegetarians.
Undercoverage could occur since individuals who are following other specific types of diets (like gluten free or low fat diets) are not specifically included in the study.
The placebo effect may cause individuals to feel like they do not have a cold when really they do.

solution:
Confounding occurs when we cannot tell whether it is the variable under study, some other variable, or some combination of variables that caused the effect that we observed.

If our study indicates that vegetarians do get fewer colds on average, we will still be unsure whether this is attributable to their self-selected vegetarian diet, a healthier lifestyle overall, some other variable common to vegetarians, or some combination of all of these things.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect. Blinding is a feature of experiments, not observational studies.

Choice 'B' is incorrect. We are often able to notice relationships between an explanatory variable (vegetarian or non-vegetarian diet) and the response variable (# of colds) in an observational study. However, an observational study may not be used to show that the type of diet is the thing that is causing the number of colds.

Choice 'D' is incorrect. Undercoverage occurs when a specific group is left out of the sample. For example, nothing here suggests that those who are following a gluten-free diet are left out of the study. The fact that they are following a gluten-free diet is simply not a variable of interest to us. However, different types of diets could present another type of confounding.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. The placebo effect is a feature of experiments, not observational studies. There was no placebo given.
